What is body confidence?🤔
🔴Body confidence is defined as the way we feel about our appearance. Being confident with your body means that you are happy with the way you look and with what your body is capable of doing.

🔴Spending time on social media can have a significant impact on our body confidence and our body image. Being that people are spending more time on social media during the COVID-19 pandemic, we must highlight the differences between what we see online and what is reality.

🔴There is a significant number of men and women who compare themselves with images they see online, and these comparisons tend to be unfavourable. We must collectively be aware of the reality behind social media, whilst also following pages that have a positive impact on our well being rather than pages that negatively impact our body image.

What is a mammogram?
➡️ A mammogram can be described as taking an x-ray picture of your breasts, and is very important in finding cancer early. Remember that the pros outweigh the cons when it comes to screening, it is better to detect any lumps early rather than not detecting them at all!

Women between the ages of 50-69 are eligible for screening as part of the National Screening programme. If you feel or see any changes in your breasts that you are concerned about speak to your family doctor.

You may also contact the Mater Dei Hospital Breast clinic on 25454573 or 25454433!

Think Pink!💗

Our next theme in our Pink October Campaign is 'Breast Self-Examination'. Self-examining your breasts can be an important way to detect any lumps, hence detecting any possible cancerous lumps, early on. It is a very useful and important screening tool that should be performed in combination with the regular mammograms, and physical examination by your doctor.

This self-exam should be made part of your regular routine, and should be performed at least once a month. Regular examination will make you more familiar with what your breasts are like normally, so if a lump is present it will be noticed easily.

Do not hesitate to call your doctor if you've noticed a lump or any other breast changes👩‍⚕️

What is sexual assault? It is to force someone into sexual activity when they are unwilling, using violence, threatening behaviour, power or coercion. Sexual assault does not necessarily include the act of sex and can also occur when the victim is unable to give consent. Absence of the word ‘no’, does not necessarily mean ‘yes’ and is not defined as consent.

Forms of sexual assault include rape, marital rape, child sexual abuse, elderly sexual assault, groping, kissing and sexual harassment, with all the above causing severe, often, long-lasting psychological problems with the victims such as depression, anxiety, post traumatic stress disorder, and addiction. That would be in addition to the physical effects suffered such as physical trauma and unwanted pregnancies.

Many victims are invalidated, and even shamed, being told that it was their fault. This may affect how, and whether, they report what had happened to them to the authorities, either to avoid reliving the trauma of the assault or due to social stigma of being a victim.

Design: Owen Cachia

Sexual assault is a punishable crime and can be defined as any form of unwanted sexual contact or behaviour that occurs without explicit consent of the recipient, this can include rape, fondling and even attempted rape. Sexual assault and/or rape are never a victim’s fault! Any individual can be a victim of sexual assault, men, women, young or old. Although incredibly common, sexual assault remains greatly underreported locally.

If you are a victim of sexual assault and would like to seek support please contact the Victim Support Malta or the Supportline on 179. If you are a victim and would like to report the assault, please contact the Victim Support Unit within the Malta Police Force.

This World AIDS Day, we recognize and celebrate the generations of HIV and AIDS activists whose trailblazing work has fundamentally changed and continues to impact the political landscape of public health and the everyday lives of people living with and affected by HIV. As we navigate the COVID-19 pandemic, there's a lot we can learn from those affected by the HIV / AIDS epidemic of the 1980s and 1990s.

The COVID-19 pandemic was marked by government coordination and action, but those on the front lines of the HIV epidemic were treated with apathy and hostility, all while taking care of each other and grieving the loss of family, partners, and community members.

The sexual health and public health sectors owe so much to the creativity, resilience, ethics and vision of everyone in the HIV/AIDS movement. They are still on the frontlines, pushing back against stigma when it comes to HIV and STIs.

Everyone deserves to be healthy and to thrive. Knowing our HIV status is a crucial part of taking care of ourselves. This year, Health Canada approved the use of the INSTI HIV Self-Test, which allows people to receive a testing kit in the mail and take a 1-minute test from their homes. With 14% of HIV-positive Canadians still undiagnosed, this is a crucial step towards making HIV and STI testing more widely available so that everyone is able to know their status and connect with community supports and treatment. To learn more about HIV self-testing, read this update by CATIE: https://www.catie.ca/en/catienews/2020-11-04/health-canada-licenses-hiv-self-testing

Diagnosing and treating other STIs is also a key part of HIV prevention work, because STIs can make us more vulnerable to HIV infection. We all deserve access to accessible, sex positive, comprehensive sexual health information and care. It’s our right. Find out more about STI testing here: https://www.actioncanadashr.org/campaigns/get-tested-stis-least-once-year

Day 15: Spotlight on women's unpaid care work

📌 Women perform 75% of all unpaid care work globally. COVID-19 has made it worse. How does this impact women workers?

📌To accommodate caregiving & domestic roles in their personal lives, women workers often seek flexible work arrangements & compromise on pay and protections. This gives rise to highly feminized sectors characterized by extremely low pay and the
absence of formal contractual arrangements.

👊 Governments must change discriminatory & stereotypical patterns [Men's work Vs Women's work] & work towards recognizing, reducing & redistributing women’s unpaid care.

Informal women workers like agricultural workers, waste
pickers, and sex workers face increased risks to their reproductive health.

December 6 marks the 31st anniversary of the Montreal Massacre in which 14 women were murdered for being female. We observe this day in remembrance of victims of femicide.

📌 Home is not the safest place for a woman. In the wake of COVID-19, there has been a surge in gender-based violence and the issue of femicide has assumed greater urgency. An increase in the number of calls to domestic violence helplines across many countries stand testimony to this.

📌 Women protesting against femicide in public spaces have been threatened with violence, fired at by state actors, physically assaulted, and killed. We strongly condemn such acts of violence and brutality in public spaces.

📌 Governments must do more to protect women from femicide in private and public spaces. Their inaction results in impunity and women are paying the price with their lives. The time for change is NOW!
